qssp.hmm module

class qssp.hmm.HMM(Ts, init_dist=None)[source]

Bases: object

A Hidden Markov Model representation of a process with basic functionality.

Ts

Numpy array of labeled transition matrices

Type

np.array

init_dist

Array containing the initial probability distribution over hidden states. If None, the stationary state distribution is used

Type

np.array

alphabet

Array containing symbols alphabet for HMM

Type

np.array

state_labels

Array containing labels for states of HMM

Type

np.array

is_unifilar()[source]

Bool- returns True if HMM is unifilar

all_words(L)[source]

Returns all possible words of length L and their probabilities

sample_transition(state)[source]

Samples a possible transition from a given hidden state, with its associated probability. Returnsnext state and the emitted symbol

sample_words(n, L)[source]

Samples and returns n words of length L

stationary_distribution()[source]

Returns the stationary state distribution of the HMM as a numpy array

state_entropy(dist=None)[source]

Returns the Shannon entropy of the given state distribution dist. If None, returns the entropy of the stationary state distribution

block_entropies(L)[source]

Returns a list of block entropies for words of length=1 to length=L

Computes and returns the (difference) entropy rate approximation at length L

Returns all possible words of length L and their probabilities :param L: Length of words to be computed :type L: int

Returns

(words, probs) are lists of allowed words and their associated probabilities

tuple

block_entropies(L)[source]

Returns a list of block entropies for words of length=0 to length=L :param L: Maximum word length for which block entropies will be computed :type L: int

Returns

List of block entropies for words from length 1 to L

Return type

list

entropy_rate_approx(L)[source]

Computes and returns the (difference) entropy rate approximation at length L :param L: Length for which entropy rate approximation is computed. :type L: int

Returns

Entropy rate approximation

Return type

float

evolve(N, init_dist=None, transients=0, word=False)[source]

takes an initial mixed state and evolves it N time steps (a single path)

Parameters

  • N (int) – Number of time steps to be computed

  • init_dist=None (None or np.array) – Initial mixed state

  • transients=0 (int) – Number of transients to be thrown away from the path.

  • word (bool, optional) – If True returns word generated during evolution

Return type

np.array with the mixed states visited in the path, will have N-transients entries

excess_entropy_approx(L)[source]

Returns the Excess Entropy approximation at length L :param L: Wordlength at which the entropy rate approximation is computed :type L: int

Returns

Excess entropy approximation

Return type

float

is_unifilar()[source]

bool - returns True if HMM is unifilar

many_paths(N, runs, init_dist=None, transients=0)[source]

Runs evolve ‘runs’ times and stitches all the resulting mixed states into one array. For any well behaved hmm and a sufficiently large number of N and runs, this should be an approximation of the msp states (w/o transitions)

N: int

number of timesteps to evolve initial state

runs: int

number of times the evolution is run (starting in the same initial state)

init_dist: np.array or None

initial state of hmm

transients: int

number of transient states to be ignored for each run of the evolution

np.array with the mixed states visited during ‘runs’ runs of length (N-transients)

sample_transition(state)[source]

Samples a possible transition from a given hidden state, with its associated probability. Returnsnext state and the emitted symbol :param state: State from which a transition will be sampled :type state: int

Returns

(new_state, symbol) are both int representing the new state and the symbol emitted during transition

Return type

tuple

sample_words(n, L)[source]

Samples and returns n words of length L :param n: Number of words to be sampled and returned :type n: int :param L: Length of words to be sampled and returned :type L: int

Returns

List of sampled words

Return type

list

state_entropy(dist=None)[source]

Returns the Shannon entropy of the given state distribution dist. If None, returns the entropy of the stationary state distribution :param dist=None: Distribution whose Shannon entropy will be computed, if None then returns Shannon Entropy of stationary state distribution :type dist=None: dist

Returns

Shannon entropy rate of state distribution

Return type

float

class qssp.q_objects.measurement(mOps, labels=None, tol_positivity=1e-08)[source]

Bases: object

A quantum measurement, consisting of a set of operators

mOps

measurement operators in matrix form

Type

list of numpy arrays

n_ops

number of measurement operators

Type

int

tol_positvity

numerical tolerance for checking positivity/completeness of measurement

Type

float

is_postive()

Returns True if all eigenvalues of measurement operators are non-negative.

is_complete()[source]

Returns True if measurement operators sum to the identity (within tolerance).

is_complete()[source]

Returns True if measurement operators sum to the identity (within tolerance), otherwise returns False.

is_positive()[source]

Returns True if all eigenvalues of measurement operators are non-negative, otherwise returns False.

class qssp.q_objects.qstate(amplitudes, test_norm=True)[source]

state

is_normalized()[source]

Returns True if state is normalized array, False otherwise

normalize()[source]

Normalizes state if not already normalized

is_hermitian()[source]

Returns True if state is Hermitian array

is_positive()[source]

Returns True if all eigenvalues of state matrix are 0 or positive, False otherwise

is_valid()[source]

Returns True if state is normalized, Hermitian and postive, False otherwise

is_pure()[source]

Returns True if state matrix is approximately idempotent

vn_entropy(base=2)[source]

Returns von Neumann entropy of state matrix with desired base

measure(measurement, labels=False)[source]

Applies measurement to state and returns probabilities of different measurement outcomes

measure_sample(measurement, num_samples)[source]

Returns measurement outcomes when applying measurement sampled ‘num_samples’ times with correct probabilities

add_noise(noise_type, noise_level)[source]

Returns state after passing it through a noisy channel.

Parameters

  • noise_type (str) – Type of noisy channel to use, can be ‘phaseflip’, ‘bitflip’, ‘bitphaseflip’, ‘depolarizing’, or ‘amplitude_damping’

  • noise_level (float) – Amount of noise to apply

is_hermitian()[source]

Returns True if state is Hermitian array.

is_normalized()[source]

Returns True if state is normalized array, False otherwise.

is_positive()[source]

Returns True if all eigenvalues of state matrix are 0 or positive, False otherwise.

is_pure()[source]

Returns True if state matrix is approximately idempotent.

is_valid()[source]

Returns True if state is normalized, Hermitian and postive, False otherwise.

measure(measurement, labels=False)[source]

Applies measurement to state and returns probabilities of different measurement outcomes.

Parameters

  • measurement (measurement class) – Measurement operators to apply to quantum state

  • labels (Boolean) – If True, returns list of strings labeling measurement outcomes, default is False

measure_sample(measurement, num_samples)[source]

Returns measurement outcomes sampled with the correct probabilities.

Parameters

measurement (instance of measurement class) –

normalize()[source]

Normalizes state if not already normalized.

vn_entropy(base=2)[source]

Returns von Neumann entropy of state matrix with desired base.

Parameters

base (real) – Base of logarithm to use (default is 2)

class qssp.qshmm.qsHMM(model, alph, noise_type='None', noise_level=0)[source]

Bases: object

A quantum state Hidden Markov Model consisting of a classical HMM and an alphabet of quantum states.

HMM

Numpy array of labeled transition matrices

Type

HMM object

alph

List of quantum states which are associated with symbols of the classical HMM

Type

list of qstates

alph_size

Size of the alphabet of quantum states

Type

int

q_word(word)[source]

Turns given classical word into quantum state using the quantum alphabet

q_words(n, L)[source]

Samples words of length L with appropriate probabilities n times and returns list associated q_words

q_block(L, join=True)[source]

Returns single quantum state represetning all words of length L or (if join == False) a quantum state and probability for each word

q_block_entropies(L)[source]

Returns a list of von Neumann entropies for blocks of length=1 to length=L

q_entropy_rate(L)[source]

Computes and returns the (difference) von Neumann entropy rate approximation at length L

q_excess_entropy(L)[source]

Returns the quantum excess entropy approximation at length L

qssp.viz module

qssp.viz.three_state_msp_scatter(x, y, filename='none')[source]

takes in list of ordered x and y values and returns a scatter plot with mixed states in the 2-simplex

qssp.viz.three_states_to_simplex(all_states)[source]

takes in an array of mixed states (from 3 state machine) and returns two ordered lists of x and y coordinates for the 2-simplex

qssp.viz.two_states_to_simplex(all_states)[source]

takes in an array of mixed states (from 2 state machine) and returns two ordered lists of x and y coordinates for the 1-simplex
